document_title: Changes in the distribution and function of leukocytes after whole-body iron ion irradiation
summary_full: This study investigated the long-term effects of whole-body iron ion irradiation (56Fe) on the immune system of C57BL/6 mice, 40 days post-exposure to doses of 0, 1, 2, and 3 gray (Gy). While organ masses like spleen, liver, and lung remained unchanged, thymus mass increased significantly in irradiated groups. In the blood, red blood cell counts, hemoglobin, and hematocrit decreased at 3 Gy, and CD8+ T cytotoxic cell counts and percentages were reduced across irradiated groups, leading to an elevated CD4:CD8 ratio. Conversely, splenic B cell counts and percentages, as well as T helper cell counts, were elevated in some irradiated groups. Bone marrow showed reduced percentages of stem cell markers (Sca-1 and CD34/Sca-1) in higher dose groups. Spontaneous blastogenesis in blood increased with irradiation, but mitogen-induced responses in the spleen were not significantly affected. The findings indicate persistent immunological abnormalities more than a month after iron ion irradiation, with compartment-specific differences.
key_findings: Whole-body iron ion irradiation (56Fe) at 1-3 Gy caused significant increases in thymus mass in mice 40 days post-exposure.

Blood analysis revealed decreased red blood cell count, hemoglobin, and hematocrit at 3 Gy, and reduced CD8+ T cytotoxic cell counts and percentages in all irradiated groups, leading to an elevated CD4:CD8 ratio.
Splenic B cell counts and percentages, along with T helper cell counts, were significantly elevated in one or more irradiated groups.
Bone marrow showed a significant decrease in cells expressing stem cell markers (Sca-1 and CD34/Sca-1) at 2 and 3 Gy.
Spontaneous blastogenesis of blood cells increased in irradiated groups, suggesting ongoing DNA synthesis.
Immunological abnormalities persist more than a month after 56Fe irradiation, with distinct effects observed in blood, spleen, and bone marrow.
future_research_fields: Investigating the long-term health consequences of persistent immune dysregulation after space radiation exposure.
Developing countermeasures to mitigate radiation-induced anemia and immune suppression during deep-space missions.
Further exploring the differential effects of various radiation types (e.g., protons, HZE ions) on the immune system.
Studying the mechanisms behind compartment-specific immune changes (blood vs. spleen vs. bone marrow) after irradiation.
Assessing the impact of combined spaceflight stressors (radiation, microgravity, confinement) on immune function.

conclusions: Forty days after whole-body 56Fe irradiation, significant immunological abnormalities persist in mice, with distinct compartment-specific effects observed in the blood, spleen, and bone marrow. These findings highlight the potential for long-term immune dysfunction following space radiation exposure, underscoring the need for further research into countermeasures and a better understanding of spaceflight stressors.
impact_statement: This study reveals persistent immune system damage in mice exposed to iron ion radiation, crucial for understanding astronaut health risks during long-duration space missions.
